title: Responsive Design With Bootstrap
author: Gabriel Petersson
description: First of all, responsive web design is about having our website for example, be more interactive when it comes to user experience. For example if a user visits our web page on the computer and later wants to visit the same web page on their phone, the elements on the web page should have adjusted to the fact that the user no longer is on a computer but on a phone. Since the screen size of a phone or any other device is smaller the web page has to adjust. Otherwise the website would not look very user friendly when visited on something other than a computer. So how do we achieve a responsive design? Thats where bootstrap comes in. Bootstrap is a very popular tool that programmers use in order to design responsive web applications. It is very easy to use because it does not require a programmer to learn, for example a new programming language. The easiest way to get started with bootstrap is to visit their site and head over to their documentation. There you can find how to get started and all the things you can do using bootstrap. However what you might want to learn is some of the commands that bootstrap uses to speed up your development. Most of the commands that bootstrap use are added to the HTML class names. An important part when starting with bootstrap is that you need to include the script/javascript file and the css file that bootstrap is run upon. If you include these files in the header of your HTML file, you are good to go and can use the bootstrap commands and features as you want. When it comes to responsiveness bootstrap uses a six-tier grid that decides how things will render on different devices.

title: HTML - an introduction
author: Gabriel Petersson
description: HTML stands for hypertext markup language. Just by looking at the full name it is somewhat self explanatory that HTML is a markup language and not a programming language. The main reason that it is not, is that it is unable to make dynamic functionality. In programming,  HTML is used to create elements that are to be displayed on a web page. You can think of HTML as a skeleton that represents the web page. So when a web page is loaded the HTML file and its elements instruct the browser on how to display the content of the web page.   An important thing to understand is that HTML does not style any of these elements. In other words HTML can for example not add color to a button. All elements have opening and closing tags to specify where the element starts and finishes. In these tags it is also specified what type of element it is. It could for example be a button or a paragraph. A HTML element can also have content. So for example if you create a button element and write “button” in between the opening and closing tags, there would be text on the button saying “button”. Another part of an element is the attribute. The attribute adds some additional information about the element. So if you would want to access a specific HTML element you might need to add an id as an attribute. Although most of the HTML elements have an opening and closing tag, some of them just need an opening tag. For example if you were to add an image to your HTML you only need an opening tag. This is because an image does not need/have any content. Almost all web pages that we see today do not only rely on HTML. There other languages used to create a fully functioning web page.

title: CSS - an introduction
author: Gabriel Petersson
description: CSS stands for Cascading style sheets and is used to style for example a HTML document. Although CSS can also style XML documents. If you for example have a HTML document that has some elements, for example a button. CSS is the thing that styles the button, making it change color, position, size and so on. If you have heard about HTML you might know that it is not a programming language and neither is CSS. CSS is considered a style sheet language. So how would you access a specific element from a HTML file in order to style it? First you need to include a reference in the HTML document that points to your css file. Then you start by adding a selector. A selector is the part that points to the element that is to be styled. For example if you have a button with the id: “myButton”, you can access this button by writing “#myButton{}” in the CSS document. The “#” sign specifies that you are looking for an element that has an id, which of course has the name myButton. Inside the curly parentheses you can write your CSS commands in order to style the element. Here you could for example write “background-color: blue”, which would make the background color of the button turn blue. The things that we write inside the curly parentheses is called declaration. And going back to our example “background-color” is what we call a property and “blue” is what we call the property value. This entire expression is called a ruleset. And ofcourse we can have multiple declarations inside our ruleset.  Just to clarify how a ruleset can look, here is a example: “#myButton{background-color: blue;}”.

title: Javascript - an introduction
author: Gabriel Petersson
description: Javascript is a programming language that is mostly used to add functionality and interactivity to web pages. Almost all the web pages that you visit are based on HTML, CSS and javascript. When it comes to functionality and making the web page come to life, javascript makes this happen. Important thing to note is that javascript is not related to another programming language named java. Javascript is mostly used for web applications while java is more used on the backend side and for smartphone applications. The reason that javascript is used in web development is that it can interact with the DOM, which represents the web page. One of the reasons that javascript is very popular is that it has a very big library and can be used with many different frameworks such as react, angular and vue. In order to use javascript to modify a HTML document, you first need to add a script reference in the HTML file that points to the intended javascript code. If you are familiar with java or any other language that uses data types when declaring variables, you might be a bit confused with how variables are declared in javascript. The three ways that you can declare a variable in javascript is by using either var, let or const.  When using “var” the variable is function scoped meaning that it can be used anywhere inside of the function where it was decaled. Var variables can easily be overwritten and are not recommended to use unless absolutely necessary. Most variables are declared with either “let” or “const”. This is because they are block scoped meaning that this variable only can be used inside its block. You can for example not use a variable that is declared inside a loop, outside the loop. The difference between const and let is that the value of the const variable can never be changed while a let variable can. So why not use var? This is because using var is more error-prone since the value of the variable can be changed from anywhere inside the function. It is much better to use let or const since they are block scoped making it less error-prone.
